properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for Bunyip River to Iona. 

The Bunyip River catchment has recorded no rainfall since 09:00 AM Tuesday 09 January 2024. The Western Port catchment has recorded no rainfall for the same period. No rainfall is forecast for the catchment Wednesday 10 January 2024.

Water levels of the Bunyip River at various locations are now falling after responding to the rain earlier this week.

Bunyip River to Iona:
The level of the Bunyip River at Iona is currently at 1.98 metres, below the Minor Flood Level (2.10 metres), and falling.

Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn will remain closed to traffic until the level in the river drops below Minor Flood Level again.
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Donâ€™t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water
  • Check the VicTraffic website (traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au) for road closures and follow instructions from emergency services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte.

The Yarra River catchment has recorded no rainfall in the upper part of the catchment and no rainfall in the lower part of the catchment since 09:00 AM Tuesday 09 January 2024. No rainfall is forecast for the catchment for Wednesday 10 January 2024.

Water levels of the Yarra River at various locations are still responding to the rain from earlier this week.

Yarra River from Coldstream to Warrandyte:
The level of the Yarra River at Yarra Glen is currently at 4.16 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (4.10 metres), and falling slowly. It is expected to remain above the Minor Flood Level until Thursday 11 January.

Minor flooding in the Yarra River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway including bicycle paths.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Some bicycle and walking tracks will be unpassable at this level.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Donâ€™t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2024 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for Thomson River Cowwarr Weir to Wandocka

MINOR FLOODING HAS EASED AT WANDOCKA

The Thomson River at Wandocka peaked during Wednesday early morning and fell below the minor flood level (6.20 metres) during Wednesday morning.

No significant rainfall has been observed across the Thomson catchment since 9:00 am Tuesday. No significant rainfall is forecast for rest of Wednesday.

Thomson River Cowwarr Weir to Wandocka:

Minor flooding has eased along the Thomson River Cowwarr Weir to Wandocka

The Thomson River at Wandocka peaked at 6.34 metres around 01:36 am Wednesday 10 January and is currently at 6.07 metres and falling, below the minor flood level (6.20 metres). The Thomson River at Wandocka is likely to remain below the minor flood level (6.20 m).
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.

  •  Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides â€“ be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for water quality at Lake Bolac. 
  • High levels of blue-green algae have been detected in the lake. 
  • The algal bloom is expected to remain until there is significant rainfall to flush the lake or cooler conditions slow the algae. 
  • Regular testing is being conducted to identify new outbreaks or changes that might indicate improved water quality. 
  • This notification will be reviewed weekly and updated as the situation changes.
Warning signs have been installed at the lake.

You should avoid direct contact with affected water in Lake Bolac.

Do not swim in affected areas or use water for cooking, drinking, washing or showering. Boiling the water will not make it safe. 
What you should do:
  • Visit Parks Victoria website (https://www.parks.vic.gov.au/places-to-see/parks/lake-bolac-highway-park) for more information. 
  • Observe information signs posted at the lake.
Protect your health:
  • Direct contact with water affected by blue green algae can cause skin irritation, sore eyes, ears and nose. If swallowed it can cause cramps, nausea and vomiting. 
  • If you do come into contact with affected water, wash your skin immediately in clean cool water. 
  • Boiling affected water does not make it safe to drink. Boiling water bursts the blue green algae cells and releases toxins into the water making it more likely that you will experience symptoms. 
  • If you are experiencing any health issues after contact with affected water seek medical advice from your local doctor or Nurse-On-Call on 1300 60 60 24.
Protect your pets:
  • Pet owners should prevent pets from drinking or having direct contact with contaminated water. 
Agriculture information: 
  • Irrigation water contaminated with blue-green algae should not be spray irrigated on vegetables and fruit, or come in contact with plants being grown for food during processing and packing. 
  • Fruit and vegetables grown in the affected areas are safe to consume if farmers follow recommendations regarding blue-green algae
Impacts in your area:
  • The water is  green as a result of the algae bloom.
Boating and fishing:
  • Boating and fishing is still allowed in these areas, however care needs to be taken.
  • Fish caught from affected areas should be rinsed and cleaned thoroughly in fresh water, and internal organs removed from the fish and discarded before eating. 
  • Do not eat mussels, crayfish or yabbies caught from the affected area. 
This message was issued by Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action.

The next update is expected by 31/01/2024 04:20 pm or as the situation changes.

Information about blue green algae:
  • For information on blue green algae visit: www2.health.vic.gov.au/public-health/water/blue-green-algae-cyanobac teria.
Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter.
  • Tune into ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River Seymour to Murchison.
This is an update, replacing the Watch and Act message issued at 10.10am this morning. 

MURCHISON STEADY AT A PEAK ABOVE THE MODERATE FLOOD LEVEL

No significant rainfall was recorded across the Goulburn River catchment in the 24 hours to 3:00 pm Wednesday, and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

The main flood peak along the Goulburn River is now at Murchison, where moderate flooding is occurring. As these floodwaters extend downstream, moderate flooding is possible at Shepparton and McCoys Bridge from late this week.

Releases from Lake Eildon have been increased to 5000 ML/day.

Peak forecasts will be further refined as upstream peaks are observed.
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
If you choose to leave:
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications.
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding.
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace.
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave.
If you are travelling:
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route.
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave:
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated.
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow.
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
If you are camping: Close to a creek or river, you may be at risk of flooding and need to move to higher ground, away from waterways.

Impacts in your area:

Impacts in your area:
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.

This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2024 11:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice is being issued for Poowong, Loch and Nyora residents. 
  • The tap water in Poowong, Loch and Nyora is not safe to drink without boiling first. 
  • A boil water advisory has been issued following reports of contaminated water in the Poowong-Loch-Nyora water supply system.
  • Consumption of unboiled water can cause gastro-like symptoms. If you experience any of these symptoms, please contact your GP and inform your GP of this advisory.
  • This is an updated Advice message that replaces the Advice issued at 9:53 am on Friday 5 January 2024.
If you live or work within Poowong, Loch and Nyora, you must boil tap water before drinking. Or drink bottled water.
What you should do:  
  • Boil water before drinking it, or drink bottled water.  
  • Boil water for washing and preparing food, preparing beverages, making ice and for preparing baby formula. 
  • Boil water for brushing teeth.
To ensure water is safe to drink you should: 
  • Heat water until a continuous and rapid stream of air-bubbles is produced from the bottom of a pan or kettle (kettles with automatic shut-off switches are suitable, variable temperature kettles should be set to boil).
  • Allow water to cool before use.
  • Store water in a clean, closed container for later use.
  • Be careful when boiling water to prevent scalding or burns. 
It is safe to use unboiled water for:
  • Washing your hands
  • Cleaning dishes - use hot soapy water and let them air dry before using them again or use a dishwasher. 
  • Washing clothes.
  • Showering and bathing in. Young children should be given a sponge bath to avoid them accidentally swallowing the water. 
  • Garden watering. If you grow fruits and vegetables then they will need to be washed with cooled boiled water before you eat them.
  • Flushing toilets.
For health advice:
  • Call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24 or see your doctor if you require medical advice.
Impacts in your area: 
  • South Gippsland Water advises customers in Poowong, Loch and Nyora to boil their drinking water until further notice. 
  • Water trailers are available at Nyora Recreational Reserve, Poowong Recreational Reserve, Main Street Loch and Speight Street in Loch from 9:30 am on 04/01/2024.
  • Further details can be found at https://www.sgwater.com.au/alerts
This message was issued by Department of Health.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2024 03:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter
  • ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline. 
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Pyramid Creek downstream of Kow Swamp
properties.webBody:
This Flood Advice is being issued for Pyramid Creek downstream of Kow Swamp.

  • Minor flood impacts are likely to occur along Pyramid Creek downstream of Kow Swamp.
  • Goulburn-Murray Water have increased the flows from Kow Swamp to Box Creek from 1000 megalitres per day to 1500 megalitres per day for flood mitigation.
  • Flows will likely continue at a heightened rate for a few days before gradually decreasing.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do:
  • Landholders between Kow Swamp and Box Creek are advised to move machinery and cattle to higher ground, and ensure that any privately owned levees are of an adequate standard. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes. 
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

For more information on the increased flows from Kow Swamp to Box Creek, contact Goulburn-Murray Water on 1800 013 357.
Impacts in your area:
  • Floodwater will generally be contained within the banks along Pyramid Creek.
  • There may be some locations where floodwater impacts private land adjacent to the creek.
  • Emergency Services and contractors are undertaking works to repair a number of priority breaches. Please stay clear of machinery operating in the area.
  • Not all breaches will be repaired. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service 

The next update is expected by 12/01/2024 02:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (Vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Moderate Flood Warning is being issued for Goulburn River Murchison to Shepparton.
This Watch and Act message replaces the Watch and Act - Prepare Now message issued at 11.23am this morning. 

MURCHISON STEADY AT A PEAK ABOVE THE MODERATE FLOOD LEVEL

MODERATE FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SHEPPARTON AND MCCOYS BRIDGE FROM AROUND FRIDAY MORNING

No significant rainfall was recorded across the Goulburn River catchment in the 24 hours to 3:00 pm Wednesday, and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.

The main flood peak along the Goulburn River is now at Murchison, where moderate flooding is occurring. As these floodwaters extend downstream, moderate flooding is possible at Shepparton and McCoys Bridge from late this week.

Releases from Lake Eildon have been increased to 5000 ML/day.

Peak forecasts will be further refined as upstream peaks are observed.

  • Moderate flooding is occurring along the Goulburn River at Murchison and is possible at Shepparton.
  • The Goulburn River at Murchison is currently steady at a peak near 10.50 metres, with moderate flooding. The Goulburn River at Murchison is likely to fall below the moderate flood level (10.20 metres) overnight Wednesday into Thursday. The river level may fall below the minor flood level (9.00 metres) during Friday.  

Act now - take actions immediately to protect your life and property, and move to higher ground.
What you should do:

  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Turn off gas and electricity at your home or workplace. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Do not enter flooded areas. Turn around a find a safe alternative route. 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
  • Use plugs, sandbags or household items to block toilets, sinks and drains to stop sewerage backflow. 
  • Lift it - move valuables and vital household items up on high surfaces, such as on top of tables, chairs, benches and beds.
Impacts in your area:  
  • Flooding above floor level of a single-story home is likely to occur in some locations.

ROAD CLOSURES:
Murchison: 
Old Weir Road, from Station Street to end of Road
Station Street from Old Weir Road to end of road
Watson Street from Old Weir Road to end of Road

Toolamba:
Bridge Road between Newnham Road and Wren Street

Mooroopna:
Watt Road between McLennan Street, Mooroopna and Riverview Drive Kialla

Kialla:
Raftery Road from Edgewater Road to Sevens Creek Drive 

This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 11/01/2024 11:00 am or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Bunyip River downstream of Iona.

The Bunyip River catchment has recorded no rainfall since 09:00 AM Tuesday 09 January 2024. The Western Port catchment has recorded no rainfall for the same period. No rainfall is forecast for the catchment Wednesday 10 January 2024.

Water levels of the Bunyip River at various locations are now falling after responding to the rain earlier this week.

Bunyip River downstream of Iona:
The level of the Bunyip River at Cora Lynn is currently at 3.65 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (3.10 metres), and falling. It is expected to remain above the Minor Flood Level for the next few days.

Minor flooding in the Bunyip River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway. The ford at Cora Lynn will remain closed to traffic until the level in the river drops below Minor Flood Level again.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Some bicycle and walking tracks will be unpassable at this level.

  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/

Impacts in your area:

  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Cape Conran.

  • Due to a whale carcass there could be an increase in shark activity.
  • A whale carcass can attract sharks to the area and mean they are closer to the shore than normal.
  • While it is not uncommon for sharks to be present off the Victorian coast, you should exercise additional caution in the area.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice issued at 10:10 AM 2 January 2024. 
Avoid the area. Stay informed and do not enter the water at closed beaches.
What you should do:

  • If you see sharks, report the sighting by calling Triple Zero (000) or notify lifesavers immediately if you are at a patrolled beach.
Staying safe at nearby beaches:
  • Always swim, dive or surf with a friend.
  • Swim between the red and yellow flags on patrolled beaches.
  • Don't swim in places where human or animal waste enters the water.
  • Keep away from large schools of fish, seals or other wildlife as these can attract sharks.
Impacts in your area:
  • The Victorian Fisheries Authority is monitoring for shark sightings and providing advice to relevant authorities. 
This message was issued by Victorian Fisheries Authority.

The next update is expected by 16/01/2024 02:40 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.   
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.

Incident Location: Yarra River from Warrandyte to Abbotsford
Issue Date: Wednesday 10 January 2024, 11:38 am
Next Update: Thursday 11 January 2024, 12:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32369/moreinfo

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Yarra River from Warrandyte to Abbotsford.

The Yarra River catchment has recorded no rainfall in the upper part of the catchment and no rainfall in the lower part of the catchment since 09:00 AM Tuesday 09 January 2024. No rainfall is forecast for the catchment for Wednesday 10 January 2024.

Water levels of the Yarra River at various locations are still responding to the rain from earlier this week. 

Yarra River from Warrandyte to Abbottsford:
The level of the Yarra River at Heidelberg is currently at 6.49 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (6.00 metres), and falling slowly. It is expected to remain above the Minor Flood Level until Thursday 11 January.

The level of the Yarra River at Alphington is currently at 3.34 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (3.00 metres), and falling slowly. It peaked at 4.13 metres yesterday, above the Minor Flood Level. It is expected to remain above the minor flood level until Thursday 11 January.

The level of the Yarra River at Abbotsford is currently at 3.44 metres, exceeding the Minor Flood Level (2.70 metres), and falling slowly. It peaked at 4.21 metres yesterday, above the Minor Flood Level. It is expected to remain above the minor flood level until Thursday 11 January.

Minor flooding in the Yarra River catchment is affecting low-lying areas adjacent to the waterway including bicycle paths. 

Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.

properties.name: Advice
properties.webBody:
The Emergency Warning to evacuate, following flooding at Rochester has been lifted.

  • It is now Safe to Return with caution.
  • Dangerous hazards including floodwater, mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees may still be present.
  • Emergency Services remain in the area undertaking impact assessments. Additional hazards may still be present in the area. Return with caution. 
  • This Advice message replaces the Watch and Act issued at 5:29pm on Tuesday 9 January.
It is now safe to return to the evacuated area to assess impacts as the threat is reduced. Be aware of any hazards that may still exist in the warning area. 
 What you should do:
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.
  • Find alternative travel routes if roads are flooded.
  • Be aware of driving hazards, such as mud, debris, damaged roads and fallen trees. 
  • If cleaning after damage has occurred, protect your health and safety. Wear strong boots, gloves and protective clothing and wash your hands and clothes regularly.
  • Contaminated sandbags must be disposed of carefully and never reused.
If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.
Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.

Relief and Recovery:
  • The Relief Centre at Echuca South Recreation Reserve (246 High Street, Echuca) will be closing at 5:00pm today, Wednesday 10 January. Support remains available to those who require it by calling the Flood Recovery Hotline on 1800 560 760.  
  • Portable toilets and showers are available at Apex Park (Queens Street) and at the corner of Pascoe St and Bain St, Rochester.
  • The Campaspe Shire Council Recovery Centre located at the RRRR (Rochester Racecourse and Recreation Reserve) is currently open Monday to Friday 8:30am - 5:00pm.
  • More information is available on the Campaspe Shire Council Flood Recovery Webpage. More information is also available at Vic Emergency: Relief & Recovery
Impacts in your area:
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area.
  • Emergency services remain in and around the Rochester area undertaking assessments.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Mosquitoes will breed in warm stagnant water after flood waters recede. For more information on protecting yourself please visit: Better Health: Mosquitoes
  • No roads are currently closed in Rochester as a result of flooding. However, roads may still be impacted by floodwater. Never drive through floodwater. 
  • Keep up to date on road closures by visiting VicTraffic
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning issued for this flood.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Warning
properties.location: Areas near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Tremont and Ferny Creek
properties.webBody:
This Warning is being issued for areas near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Ferny Creek.

  • A landslide has occurred in the area near the Mount Dandenong Tourist Road in Ferny Creek.
  • The landslide is approximately 40 metres wide, 70 metres long and 4 metres deep.
Stay safe by avoiding damaged buildings, fallen trees and powerlines, blocked or damaged roads. Be aware of other hazards caused by the landslide.
What you should do:

If another landslide occurs, act quickly:
  • If you are outside during a landside, move quickly and keep clear of embankments, trees, powerlines and poles.
  • If you are inside, move to the part of building that is furthest away from the approaching landslide and take shelter under a table or bench.
Avoid the area:
  • Stay away from the impacted area to allow emergency services to help affected communities.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

Driving:
  • Plan your trip in advance - travel may take longer due to closed roads and poor driving conditions.
Impacts in your area:
The landslide has resulted in:
  • The Mount Dandenong Tourist Road is closed between Churchill Drive and Mast Gully Road and may remain closed for some time. For more information on road closures go to www.traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Properties have been impacted.
  • Emergency services are aware of a minor natural gas leak and the gas company is monitoring the situation. Once access is available to the site of the leak, it will be repaired.   
  • Fallen power lines and power disruptions. 
  • Fallen trees and branches.
  • Emergency tree works are commencing today to remove hazardous trees in the landslide site.  
  • Dangerous road conditions.
  • Work is being undertaken to reconnect power. 
  • Public Transport has been impacted by the landslide. You should check www.ptv.vic.gov.au/live-travel-updates for the latest updates on services.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2024 10:00 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au.
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226.
  • VicEmergency app.
  • Facebook or Twitter (#viclandslide).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

properties.name: Watch & Act
properties.webBody:
This Watch and Act message is being issued for Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.
  • Significant rainfall occurred over the past week in the Bendigo Creek Catchment. 
  • Widespread moderate flooding is developing along the Bendigo Creek downstream of Minto.
  • These floodwaters continue to move downstream affecting locations including Tandarra, Dingee, Prairie and Mitiamo.
  • From Wednesday through Friday, these floodwaters are likely to affect locations including Pyramid Hill and Kow Swamp. 
This Watch and Act replaces the previous Watch and Act message published at 3:10pm on Tuesday 09 January. 
Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.
What you should do: 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater. 
  • Farmers should moving livestock and machinery away from flooded areas.
  • Decide if you will evacuate if it becomes necessary. 
If you choose to leave: 
  • Remember to take your pets, mobile phone, spare clothes and medications. 
  • Travel to the home of family or friends who are in a safe location, away from flooding. 
  • Be aware of any road closures when you leave. 
If you are travelling: 
  • Be aware of road hazards including mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater. 
If you stay or if it is unsafe to leave: 
  • Make sure you have enough food, drinking water, medications and pet food to survive for three to five days in case you become isolated. 
Stay informed - listen to emergency broadcasters and monitor warnings.
Impacts in your area: 
  • A small number of properties are likely to be impacted and possibly become isolated.
  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Snakes, spiders and rats may try to find shelter in your home, even if raised.
  • Mosquitoes will breed in warm stagnant water after flood waters recede. For more information on protecting yourself please visit Better Health: Mozzies
Road Closures:
A number of roads are impacted by floodwater. 
  • The Bendigo Pyramid Road is closed between Raywood & Mitiama.
  • The Bendigo-Tennyson Road is closed between Kamarooka and Miloo.  
  • A number of other roads are closed. For more information go to VicTraffic
This message was issued by State Emergency Service. 

The next update is expected by 12/01/2024 02:00 pm or as the situation changes. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods) 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.   
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

WATCH & ACT - RIVERINE FLOOD - Avoid the Flooded Area
Incident Location: Bendigo and Bullock Creeks
Issue Date: Wednesday 10 January 2024, 08:20 pm
Next Update: Friday 12 January 2024, 02:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/32389/moreinfo

This Watch and Act message is being issued for Bendigo and Bullock Creeks.
- Significant rainfall occurred over the past week in the Bendigo Creek Catchment.  
- Widespread moderate flooding is developing along the Bendigo Creek downstream of Minto.
- These floodwaters continue to move downstream affecting locations including Tandarra, Dingee, Prairie and Mitiamo.
- From Wednesday through Friday, these floodwaters are likely to affect locations including Pyramid Hill and Kow Swamp.  

This Watch and Act replaces the previous Watch and Act message published at 3:10pm on Tuesday 09 January. 

Stay safe - avoid the flooded area. Be aware of potential hazards caused by flooding and never enter floodwater.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie
properties.webBody:
This is a Final Minor Flood Warning for Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie:

FLOODING NO LONGER OCCURRING AT D/S LAKE GLENMAGGIE

In the 24 hours to 9 am Wednesday, no significant rainfall was recorded across the Macalister River catchment, and no significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days.Releases from Lake Glenmaggie have fallen overnight, and the Lake Glenmaggie downstream gauge fell below the minor flood level early Wednesday morning.

Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie:

Flooding is no longer occurring along the Macalister River downstream of Lake Glenmaggie.

The Macalister River D/S Lake Glenmaggie is currently below the minor flood level (2.60 metres) at 2.43 metres and steady. The Macalister River D/S Lake Glenmaggie is expected to remain below the minor flood level (2.60 metres) for the next few days.
The threat of flooding is reduced. Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and beware of hazards remaining in the warning area.
What you should do:

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never enter floodwater.

If your home or business has been flooded:
  • Check for building damage before you enter.
  • Have all electrical and gas equipment professionally tested before use.
  • Clean and dry out the building as soon as possible.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. For emergency assistance from the SES call 132 500.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Damage to roads and buildings caused by flooding may still exist in your area. 
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides â€“ be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Donâ€™t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

This will be the last warning for this flood. 

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.webBody:
This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for the Dandenong Creek.

The Dandenong Creek catchment has recorded no rainfall since 09:00 AM Tuesday 09 January 2024. No rainfall is forecast for the catchment Wednesday 10 January 2024.

Water levels of the Dandenong Creek are now falling after responding to the rain earlier this week.

The level of the Dandenong Creek at Rowville (Police Road RB) is currently at 3.67 metres, below the Minor Flood Level. It peaked at 4.88 metres during the evening of Monday 08 January.

Heatherton Road remains closed between Stud Road and Monash Freeway due to floodwater.
Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
  • Monitor weather forecasts and river levels. Go to www.bom.gov.au/vic/warnings/
  • Floodwater is dangerous - never drive, walk or ride through floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Local roads may be closed and low bridges may be underwater.
  • Cyclists and walkers should be wary of tracks next to rivers.
  • For more information on road closures check the VicRoads website traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au.
  • Stagnant water can be harmful to your health. Donâ€™t swim, drink or wash in stagnant water.
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2024 05:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfloods)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.

Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

This Minor Flood Warning is being issued for Thomson River downstream of Wandocka:

MINOR FLOODING POSSIBLE AT SALE WHARF FROM FRIDAY MORNING

The Thomson River at Wandocka peaked during Wednesday early morning and fell below the minor floodlevel (6.20 metres) during Wednesday morning.

Minor flooding is possible at Sale Wharf from Friday morning as upstream floodwaters arrive.

No significant rainfall has been observed across the Thomson catchment since 9:00 am Tuesday. No significant rainfall is forecast for rest of Wednesday.

Thomson River downstream of Wandocka:

The Thomson River at Sale Wharf is currently at 1.78 metres and rising, below the minor flood level (2.40metres). The Thomson River at Sale Wharf may reach the minor flood level (2.40 metres) Friday morning.


Stay informed - monitor your local conditions and remain alert.
What you should do: 

  • Farmers should consider moving livestock and machinery to higher ground.
  • Be prepared to act if your situation changes.
  • You should stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.
  • Floodwater is toxic - never play or swim in floodwater.
Impacts in your area: 

  • High river levels and potential flooding in areas close to rivers and streams.
  • Caravan parks and camping grounds may be flooded.
  • Heavy rainfall may lead to an increased risk of landslides â€“ be aware of fallen earth, rocks, debris or trees.
  • Boating in floodwaters is dangerous due to debris, submerged trees and other hidden dangers. 
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 11/01/2024 03:30 pm or as the situation changes.
